awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Searchable, Extendible Data Archive for Neuroscience and Physiology Research
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a technology that allows scientists to share data, analyses, and analysis software programs in neuroscience fields. The creation of a searchable and accessible archive of neuroscience and physiology data and analyses will allow academics, industry scientists to examine and re-analyze this data. This re-examination may lead to meta-analyses and new observations that are not possible today due to the barriers of reading primary data and analyses from other labs. Scientists can pilot their analyses and hypotheses on accessible existing data, and scientists and companies can develop tools that can operate on data from many studies.  Data sets will be available to teachers for creation of educational material and tutorials. 

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a software tool that allows an experimenter or analyst to quickly express the file formats and data organization type as a set of parameters.  Humans and computer programs can then search and retrieve information from the data at many levels of granularity: from raw data to analyses and analyses of analyses. This technology may be extended to a cloud service that allows users to post their published data in a manner that is easily searchable and usable. Further, the architecture may allow interested third parties to re-analyze or develop meta-analyses that are also searchable and extendible. This archive may enable neuroscientists and physiologists to share data, analyses, and software tools, potentially unleashing a new era of discovery and robustness in science.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
This project explored the commercial feasibility of the Neuroscience Data Interface (NDI), a powerful software tool designed to revolutionize how neuroscience data is shared and utilized. While the NDI itself was created prior to this project, our focus was on understanding its potential for commercialization and broader impact.

Intellectual Merit:

The NDI addresses a critical need in neuroscience research by providing a standardized interface for accessing and analyzing data from diverse sources. This promotes collaboration, accelerates research, and enables the development of robust analytical tools. Our project investigated the market demand for such a tool and explored viable business models for its dissemination. 

Key Accomplishments:

  • Extensive market research: We conducted over 100 interviews with potential customers and stakeholders in the neuroscience field to understand their needs, challenges, and perspectives on the NDI. This provided valuable insights into the market landscape and potential user base for the technology.
  • Business model exploration: Through participation in the NSF I-Corps program, we gained valuable training in customer discovery, market research, and business model development. This allowed us to assess various commercialization strategies for the NDI and identify potential pathways to market.
  • Prototype refinement and validation: Based on feedback from potential users, we contributed to refining the NDI prototype and validating its functionality and user-friendliness. This iterative process ensured that the technology aligns with the needs and expectations of the research community.

Broader Impacts:

By exploring the commercialization potential of the NDI, this project has laid the groundwork for broader impacts across science and society:

  • Accelerating scientific discovery: Wider adoption of the NDI can facilitate data sharing and collaboration, leading to new insights into brain function and potential treatments for neurological disorders.
  • Improving healthcare: Enhanced understanding of the brain can translate into better diagnoses, treatments, and preventative measures for neurological conditions, benefiting patients and healthcare systems. 
  • Promoting open science: The NDI's focus on data sharing aligns with open science principles, increasing transparency and accessibility in research.
  • Stimulating economic growth: Commercialization of the NDI can create jobs and generate revenue in the biotechnology sector, contributing to economic development.
  • Enhancing education: The project's findings can inform the development of new educational programs and initiatives in neuroscience and entrepreneurship.
  • Developing human capital: Through the I-Corps program, the Entrepreneurial Lead and Technical Lead received extensive training in evaluating business ideas and developing startups. This valuable experience will benefit their future careers and contribute to a more entrepreneurial and innovative STEM workforce.

Last Modified: 12/30/2024
Modified by: Stephen D Van Hooser
